cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who caused to build qutub minar in delhi
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
The Qutub Minar is a historical monument located in Delhi, India. It was commissioned by Qutb al-Din Aibak, who was the founder of the Delhi Sultanate and a general in the army of Muhammad Ghori. The construction of the Qutub Minar began in 1193 after the defeat of the last Hindu ruler of Delhi, and it was completed by his successor, Iltutmish. The minaret was built to commemorate the victory of Islam over Hinduism and to serve as a minaret for the nearby Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque.

Answer:
Qutb al-Din Aibak caused the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who caused to build qutub minar in delhi
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["BULLET::::- The Qutub Minar is located in Qutb complex, Mehrauli in South Delhi. It was built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak of the Slave Dynasty, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutub Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more.. It is a fluted red sandstone tower, which tapers up to a height of 72.5 meters and is covered with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an.\n", 'The Mini Qutub Minar ("local:" Chhota Qutub Minar, Mini Minar, Kaushal Minar, Hastsal ki Laat) is a minaret tower in Hastsal village in Uttam Nagar, West Delhi, India. It was built in the 1650 by Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan (reign, 1628-1658) near his hunting lodge in Hasthal. The three storeyed tower is 16.87 meters (55 feet) tall and stands on a raised octagonal platform. The minar is built with bricks and clad with red sandstone. The tower structure and design resembles the Qutub Minar of Delhi and was inspired by it.\n', 'The Qutb complex are monuments and buildings from the Delhi Sultanate at Mehrauli in Delhi in India. The Qutub Minar "victory tower" in the complex, named after the religious figure Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, was begun by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, who later became the first Sultan of Delhi of the Mamluk dynasty. Construction was continued by his successor Iltutmish (a.k.a. Altamash), and finally completed much later by Firoz Shah Tughlaq, a Sultan of Delhi from the Tughlaq dynasty in 1368 AD. The Qubbat-ul-Islam Mosque (Dome of Islam), later corrupted into Quwwat-ul Islam, stands next to the Qutb Minar.\n', "Following the formation of local government by the United Front in April 1954, the anniversary of 21 February was declared a holiday and it became possible to construct the new monument. A foundation stone was laid in 1956. Sculptor Hamidur Rahman created the design of Shaheed Minar under which construction was started in 1957. Hamidur Rahman's model was a huge complex on a large area of land in the yard of Dhaka Medical College Hostel. The enormous design included a half-circular column to symbolise the mother with her fallen sons standing on the monument's central dais. Yellow and deep blue pieces of stained glass, symbolising eyes reflecting the sun, were also to be placed in the columns. The marble floor was designed to reflect the moving shadows of the columns. The basement of the Minar also included a fresco depicting the history of the language movement. A railing decorated with Bengali alphabet was to be constructed in front. Two footmarks coloured red and black, indicating the two opposite forces, were also in the design. Besides this a museum and a library were also included in Hamidur Rahman's design. A fountain shaped like an eye was also to be constructed. Rahman specifically designed the materials of the monument to withstand the area's tropical climate.\n", "Qutb ud Din Aibak, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutb Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Shamsuddin Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more. Sher Shah Suri also added an entrance to this tower while he was ruling and Humayun was in exile.\n", 'BULLET::::- 1190s – Construction of Qutub Minar started in India\n', 'Letitia Elizabeth Landon\'s poem "The Qutub Minar, Delhi" is a reflection on an engraving in Fisher\'s Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1833.\n', 'The Mini Qutub Minar structure is similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. It originally consisted of five storeys, each with a reducing diameter. A narrow staircase built inside led to the top. Each storey is surrounded by an octagonal ring in the outside with red sandstone overhanging eves (Chhajja) like in the Qutub Minar. The minar is built using Lakhori bricks.\n', 'In the early 17th century, Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan used Hastsal as one of his hunting lodges. In 1650, he commissioned the construction of a tall minaret similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. When completed, the Mini Qutub Minar was much higher than it is now. It was a tall 5 storey tower with an internal stairway leading to the domed Chhatri pavilion at the top. It was a gorgeous hunting pavilion tower in the center of an encompassing wilderness. The emperor rested in the tower top, royally-entertained with his immediate retinue after hunting in the surrounding wilderness.\n', 'The minar\'s topmost storey was damaged by lightning in 1369 and was rebuilt by Firuz Shah Tughlaq, who added another storey. In 1505, an earthquake damaged Qutub Minar; it was repaired by Sikander Lodi. On 1 September 1803, a major earthquake caused serious damage. Major Robert Smith of the British Indian Army renovated the tower in 1828 and installed a pillared cupola over the fifth storey, thus creating a sixth. The cupola was taken down in 1848, under instructions from The Viscount Hardinge, then Governor General of India. It was reinstalled at ground level to the east of Qutb Minar, where it remains. It is known as "Smith\'s Folly".\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about who caused the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. Here are the key points that may be unfamiliar or provide additional context:

1. **Historical Context**:
   - The Qutub Minar was initiated by **Qutub-ud-din Aibak**, who was the founder of the **Delhi Sultanate** and the first Sultan of the Mamluk dynasty. This establishes the significance of the monument as a symbol of the establishment of Muslim rule in India.
   - Aibak began the construction around **1192**, which situates the Qutub Minar within the broader historical timeline of the Delhi Sultanate's rise to power.

2. **Construction Timeline**:
   - The first storey was completed by Aibak, but it was **Iltutmish**, Aibak's successor and son-in-law, who completed three additional storeys by **1220**. This indicates a continuity of royal patronage and the importance of the monument to subsequent rulers.
   - The Qutub Minar underwent further modifications, including repairs and additions by **Firoz Shah Tughlaq** in **1369**, who rebuilt the top storey after it was damaged by lightning and added another storey. This highlights the ongoing significance of the structure over centuries and the involvement of multiple rulers in its maintenance and enhancement.

3. **Architectural Significance**:
   - The Qutub Minar is described as a **fluted red sandstone tower** that stands **72.5 meters** tall, adorned with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an. This not only emphasizes its architectural beauty but also its religious significance, reflecting the Islamic culture of the time.
   - The mention of the **Qubbat-ul-Islam Mosque** next to the Qutub Minar further contextualizes its importance within the Qutb complex, indicating that it was part of a larger religious and cultural site.

4. **Cultural Impact**:
   - The Qutub Minar is named after **Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki**, a revered Sufi saint, which connects the monument to the spiritual and cultural history of the region.
   - The construction of the **Mini Qutub Minar** by **Shah Jahan** in the 17th century, inspired by the original Qutub Minar, shows the lasting influence of this architectural style and its significance in Mughal architecture.

5. **Subsequent Modifications**:
   - The Qutub Minar has undergone various repairs and modifications due to natural disasters, such as earthquakes and lightning strikes, which indicates its vulnerability and the ongoing efforts to preserve it as a historical monument.

### Role of Extracted Content:
- **Historical Context**: Provides a timeline and understanding of the political landscape during the construction of the Qutub Minar, highlighting the significance of the monument in the context of the Delhi Sultanate.
- **Construction Timeline**: Illustrates the collaborative efforts of different rulers in the construction and maintenance of the Qutub Minar, emphasizing its importance as a royal project.
- **Architectural Significance**: Enhances understanding of the monument's design and cultural relevance, which is crucial for appreciating its historical value.
- **Cultural Impact**: Connects the monument to broader cultural and religious narratives, enriching the understanding of its significance beyond mere architecture.
- **Subsequent Modifications**: Highlights the ongoing relevance and preservation efforts, indicating that the Qutub Minar is not just a relic of the past but a living part of India's historical narrative.

By synthesizing this information, we can confidently answer that the Qutub Minar was primarily commissioned by **Qutub-ud-din Aibak**, with significant contributions from his successor **Iltutmish** and later modifications by **Firoz Shah Tughlaq**.

This connection underscores the military and political motivations behind the construction of the minaret, which symbolized the establishment of Muslim rule in a region that had previously been under Hindu control.
   - The construction began around **1192**, shortly after Aibak's victory over the last Hindu ruler of Delhi, marking a pivotal moment in Indian history.

2. **Construction Timeline**:
   - Aibak completed the first storey, but it was his successor and son-in-law, **Iltutmish**, who added three more storeys by **1220**. This continuity of construction reflects the importance of the Qutub Minar as a royal project that served to legitimize the Sultanate's power.
   - The Qutub Minar has undergone several modifications over the centuries, including repairs by **Firoz Shah Tughlaq** in **1369** after a lightning strike damaged the top storey. This highlights the ongoing significance of the monument and the commitment of subsequent rulers to its preservation.

3. **Architectural Significance**:
   - The Qutub Minar is a **fluted red sandstone tower** standing at **72.5 meters** tall, adorned with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an. This architectural style reflects the Islamic culture of the time and serves as a testament to the artistic achievements of the period.

   - The Qutub Minar has faced challenges from natural disasters, such as earthquakes and lightning strikes, leading to various repairs and modifications. This ongoing preservation effort indicates its importance as a historical monument and a symbol of India's architectural heritage.

### Answer:
Qutub-ud-din Aibak caused the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi, beginning around 1192. His successor, Iltutmish, completed additional storeys by 1220, and later modifications were made by Firoz Shah Tughlaq. The Qutub Minar stands as a symbol of the establishment of Muslim rule in India and reflects the architectural and cultural achievements of the time.

The Qutub Minar, a prominent historical monument in Delhi, was initiated by Qutub-ud-din Aibak, the founder of the Delhi Sultanate, around 1192. This construction marked the beginning of a significant architectural endeavor in India, reflecting the Islamic influence on Indian architecture during the medieval period. Aibak's successor, Iltutmish, who was also his son-in-law, completed three additional storeys of the minaret by 1220. The Qutub Minar stands at a height of 72.5 meters and is characterized by its fluted red sandstone design, adorned with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an. It is part of the larger Qutb complex, which includes other significant structures, such as the Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, further emphasizing the cultural and religious significance of the site.

The passages also mention the Mini Qutub Minar, constructed by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in the 1650s, which was inspired by the original Qutub Minar. This highlights the enduring influence of the Qutub Minar on subsequent architectural projects in India.

In summary, the foundational knowledge extracted from the passages includes:

1. **Construction Timeline**: Qutub-ud-din Aibak initiated the Qutub Minar around 1192, Iltutmish completed it in 1220, and Firoz Shah Tughlaq made further modifications in 1369.
2. **Architectural Features**: The minar is made of red sandstone, features intricate carvings, and stands at 72.5 meters tall.
3. **Cultural Significance**: The Qutub Minar is part of the Qutb complex, which holds historical and religious importance.
4. **Influence on Later Architecture**: The Mini Qutub Minar, built by Shah Jahan, showcases the lasting impact of the original structure on Mughal architecture.

This consolidated understanding not only answers the question of who caused the construction of the Qutub Minar but also situates it within a broader historical and cultural context, enhancing comprehension of its significance in Indian history.

Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

The Qutub Minar is a significant historical monument located in Delhi, India, and its construction is a reflection of the Islamic architectural influence during the medieval period. The initiative to build the Qutub Minar was taken by Qutub-ud-din Aibak, who was the founder of the Delhi Sultanate and a general in the army of Muhammad Ghori. The construction began around 1192, shortly after Aibak's victory over the last Hindu ruler of Delhi, marking a pivotal moment in the establishment of Islamic rule in the region.

Aibak's intention behind the construction of the Qutub Minar was not only to commemorate this victory but also to serve as a minaret for the nearby Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, which was the first mosque built in India. This dual purpose highlights the minaret's significance in both religious and historical contexts.

The construction of the Qutub Minar was a multi-generational effort. After Aibak's death, his son-in-law Iltutmish completed three additional storeys of the minaret by 1220, further enhancing its height and architectural complexity. The structure was later modified by Firoz Shah Tughlaq in 1369 after it was damaged by lightning; he repaired the top storey and added an additional one, bringing the total height to 72.5 meters. The Qutub Minar is characterized by its fluted red sandstone design, intricate carvings, and verses from the Qur'an, which are essential features of Indo-Islamic architecture.

Additionally, the Qutub Minar is part of the larger Qutb complex, which includes other significant structures, emphasizing its cultural and religious importance. The influence of the Qutub Minar extended beyond its time, inspiring later architectural projects, such as the Mini Qutub Minar built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in the 1650s.

In summary, the enhanced understanding of the Qutub Minar's construction includes:

1. **Initiator and Historical Context**: Qutub-ud-din Aibak commissioned the Qutub Minar around 1192 after defeating the last Hindu ruler, symbolizing the establishment of Islamic rule.
2. **Construction Timeline**: Aibak started the construction, Iltutmish completed it in 1220, and Firoz Shah Tughlaq made modifications in 1369.
3. **Architectural Features**: The minar is made of red sandstone, stands at 72.5 meters tall, and features intricate carvings and Qur'anic verses.
4. **Cultural Significance**: It serves as a minaret for the Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque and is part of the Qutb complex, highlighting its religious importance.
5. **Influence on Later Architecture**: The Qutub Minar inspired later structures, such as the Mini Qutub Minar, showcasing its lasting impact on Indian architecture.

This comprehensive understanding not only answers the question of who caused the construction of the Qutub Minar but also situates it within a broader historical and cultural context, enhancing comprehension of its significance in Indian history.

**Answer:**
Qutub-ud-din Aibak caused the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi, which was later completed by his successor Iltutmish.

logician.content:
You are a logician, to answer the following question:
who caused to build qutub minar in delhi
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["BULLET::::- The Qutub Minar is located in Qutb complex, Mehrauli in South Delhi. It was built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak of the Slave Dynasty, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutub Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more.. It is a fluted red sandstone tower, which tapers up to a height of 72.5 meters and is covered with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an.
", 'The Mini Qutub Minar ("local:" Chhota Qutub Minar, Mini Minar, Kaushal Minar, Hastsal ki Laat) is a minaret tower in Hastsal village in Uttam Nagar, West Delhi, India. It was built in the 1650 by Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan (reign, 1628-1658) near his hunting lodge in Hasthal. The three storeyed tower is 16.87 meters (55 feet) tall and stands on a raised octagonal platform. The minar is built with bricks and clad with red sandstone. The tower structure and design resembles the Qutub Minar of Delhi and was inspired by it.
', 'The Qutb complex are monuments and buildings from the Delhi Sultanate at Mehrauli in Delhi in India. The Qutub Minar "victory tower" in the complex, named after the religious figure Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, was begun by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, who later became the first Sultan of Delhi of the Mamluk dynasty. Construction was continued by his successor Iltutmish (a.k.a. Altamash), and finally completed much later by Firoz Shah Tughlaq, a Sultan of Delhi from the Tughlaq dynasty in 1368 AD. The Qubbat-ul-Islam Mosque (Dome of Islam), later corrupted into Quwwat-ul Islam, stands next to the Qutb Minar.
', "Following the formation of local government by the United Front in April 1954, the anniversary of 21 February was declared a holiday and it became possible to construct the new monument. A foundation stone was laid in 1956. Sculptor Hamidur Rahman created the design of Shaheed Minar under which construction was started in 1957. Hamidur Rahman's model was a huge complex on a large area of land in the yard of Dhaka Medical College Hostel. The enormous design included a half-circular column to symbolise the mother with her fallen sons standing on the monument's central dais. Yellow and deep blue pieces of stained glass, symbolising eyes reflecting the sun, were also to be placed in the columns. The marble floor was designed to reflect the moving shadows of the columns. The basement of the Minar also included a fresco depicting the history of the language movement. A railing decorated with Bengali alphabet was to be constructed in front. Two footmarks coloured red and black, indicating the two opposite forces, were also in the design. Besides this a museum and a library were also included in Hamidur Rahman's design. A fountain shaped like an eye was also to be constructed. Rahman specifically designed the materials of the monument to withstand the area's tropical climate.
", "Qutb ud Din Aibak, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutb Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Shamsuddin Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more. Sher Shah Suri also added an entrance to this tower while he was ruling and Humayun was in exile.
", 'BULLET::::- 1190s – Construction of Qutub Minar started in India
', 'Letitia Elizabeth Landon's poem "The Qutub Minar, Delhi" is a reflection on an engraving in Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1833.
', 'The Mini Qutub Minar structure is similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. It originally consisted of five storeys, each with a reducing diameter. A narrow staircase built inside led to the top. Each storey is surrounded by an octagonal ring in the outside with red sandstone overhanging eves (Chhajja) like in the Qutub Minar. The minar is built using Lakhori bricks.
', 'In the early 17th century, Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan used Hastsal as one of his hunting lodges. In 1650, he commissioned the construction of a tall minaret similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. When completed, the Mini Qutub Minar was much higher than it is now. It was a tall 5 storey tower with an internal stairway leading to the domed Chhatri pavilion at the top. It was a gorgeous hunting pavilion tower in the center of an encompassing wilderness. The emperor rested in the tower top, royally-entertained with his immediate retinue after hunting in the surrounding wilderness.
', 'The minar's topmost storey was damaged by lightning in 1369 and was rebuilt by Firuz Shah Tughlaq, who added another storey. In 1505, an earthquake damaged Qutub Minar; it was repaired by Sikander Lodi. On 1 September 1803, a major earthquake caused serious damage. Major Robert Smith of the British Indian Army renovated the tower in 1828 and installed a pillared cupola over the fifth storey, thus creating a sixth. The cupola was taken down in 1848, under instructions from The Viscount Hardinge, then Governor General of India. It was reinstalled at ground level to the east of Qutb Minar, where it remains. It is known as "Smith's Folly".
']

4. **Complex Event Analysis**:

5. **Error Correction and Adaptation**:

The Qutub Minar is a significant historical monument located in Delhi, India, and its construction is attributed to several key figures in the Delhi Sultanate. The reasoning process begins with identifying the initiator of the construction and then considers the contributions of subsequent rulers.

1. **Initiation of Construction**: 
   - The construction of the Qutub Minar was initiated by **Qutub-ud-din Aibak** around **1192**. He was the founder of the Delhi Sultanate and a general under Muhammad Ghori. His motivation for building the minar was to commemorate the victory of Islam over the last Hindu ruler of Delhi.

2. **Completion of Storeys**:
   - After Aibak's death, his son-in-law **Iltutmish** continued the work and completed three additional storeys by **1220**. This indicates a direct succession in the project, highlighting the continuity of leadership and vision in the construction.

3. **Subsequent Modifications**:
   - The Qutub Minar underwent further modifications and repairs over the years. In **1369**, a lightning strike damaged the top storey, which was then replaced and an additional storey added by **Firoz Shah Tughlaq**. This illustrates the ongoing maintenance and adaptation of the monument to preserve its structure.

4. **Historical Context**:
   - The Qutub Minar is part of the **Qutb complex**, which includes other significant monuments from the Delhi Sultanate, emphasizing its importance as a cultural and architectural landmark. It is named after **Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki**, a revered Sufi saint, which adds a layer of religious significance to the structure.

5. **Causal Relationships**:
   - The reasoning process identifies causal relationships, such as how Aibak's victory led to the commissioning of the minar, and how subsequent rulers contributed to its completion and preservation. This understanding of causality is crucial for analyzing historical events.

8. **Complex Event Analysis**:

### Answer:
Qutub-ud-din Aibak caused the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi, beginning around 1192, to commemorate the victory of Islam over the last Hindu ruler. His successor, Iltutmish, completed additional storeys by 1220, and later modifications were made by Firoz Shah Tughlaq after a lightning strike damaged the structure in 1369. The Qutub Minar is part of the Qutb complex and is named after the revered Sufi saint Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, reflecting its cultural and religious significance.

The Qutb complex are monuments and buildings from the Delhi Sultanate at Mehrauli in Delhi in India. The Qutub Minar "victory tower" in the complex, named after the religious figure Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, was begun by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, who later became the first Sultan of Delhi of the Mamluk dynasty. Construction was continued by his successor Iltutmish (a.k.a. Altamash), and finally completed much later by Firoz Shah Tughlaq, a Sultan of Delhi from the Tughlaq dynasty in 1368 AD. The Qubbat-ul-Islam Mosque (Dome of Islam), later corrupted into Quwwat-ul Islam, stands next to the Qutb Minar.
Following the formation of local government by the United Front in April 1954, the anniversary of 21 February was declared a holiday and it became possible to construct the new monument. A foundation stone was laid in 1956. Sculptor Hamidur Rahman created the design of Shaheed Minar under which construction was started in 1957. Hamidur Rahman's model was a huge complex on a large area of land in the yard of Dhaka Medical College Hostel. The enormous design included a half-circular column to symbolise the mother with her fallen sons standing on the monument's central dais. Yellow and deep blue pieces of stained glass, symbolising eyes reflecting the sun, were also to be placed in the columns. The marble floor was designed to reflect the moving shadows of the columns. The basement of the Minar also included a fresco depicting the history of the language movement. A railing decorated with Bengali alphabet was to be constructed in front. Two footmarks coloured red and black, indicating the two opposite forces, were also in the design. Besides this a museum and a library were also included in Hamidur Rahman's design. A fountain shaped like an eye was also to be constructed. Rahman specifically designed the materials of the monument to withstand the area's tropical climate.
Qutb ud Din Aibak, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutb Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Shamsuddin Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more. Sher Shah Suri also added an entrance to this tower while he was ruling and Humayun was in exile.
BULLET::::- 1190s – Construction of Qutub Minar started in India
Letitia Elizabeth Landon's poem "The Qutub Minar, Delhi" is a reflection on an engraving in Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1833.
The Mini Qutub Minar structure is similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. It originally consisted of five storeys, each with a reducing diameter. A narrow staircase built inside led to the top. Each storey is surrounded by an octagonal ring in the outside with red sandstone overhanging eves (Chhajja) like in the Qutub Minar. The minar is built using Lakhori bricks.
In the early 17th century, Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan used Hastsal as one of his hunting lodges. In 1650, he commissioned the construction of a tall minaret similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. When completed, the Mini Qutub Minar was much higher than it is now. It was a tall 5 storey tower with an internal stairway leading to the domed Chhatri pavilion at the top. It was a gorgeous hunting pavilion tower in the center of an encompassing wilderness. The emperor rested in the tower top, royally-entertained with his immediate retinue after hunting in the surrounding wilderness.
The minar's topmost storey was damaged by lightning in 1369 and was rebuilt by Firuz Shah Tughlaq, who added another storey. In 1505, an earthquake damaged Qutub Minar; it was repaired by Sikander Lodi. On 1 September 1803, a major earthquake caused serious damage. Major Robert Smith of the British Indian Army renovated the tower in 1828 and installed a pillared cupola over the fifth storey, thus creating a sixth. The cupola was taken down in 1848, under instructions from The Viscount Hardinge, then Governor General of India. It was reinstalled at ground level to the east of Qutb Minar, where it remains. It is known as "Smith's Folly".
